title: Do Ethernet splitters slow down connection? - Quora

response.answer_text: In most cases, no. Ethernet cable has 4 pairs of wires. For 10 Mbps or 100 Mbps, one pair is used for transmit, one for receive. The other two pairs aren’t used. A pair of splitters (one on each end) uses the unused wire pairs to add a transmit and receive path for a second device. You get two connections with one cable for just pennies of cost. For 1 Gbps, two pairs are used for transmit, two pairs for receive. Each transmit pair and each receive pair work at 500 Mbps. By using both pairs, the cable can work at 1 Gbps. You cannot use splitter because all the wires are already used. If you have a long cable, it’s possible the various signals will interfere with each other. If your 100 Mbps Ethernet cable is at the edge and you add two more signals using a splitter, it’s possible the new signals will interfere with the old. But in most cases, you’ll be fine.

There is no such thing as an Ethernet splitter. There are only hubs and switches. Based on your question I’m going to make an assumption that you are talking about internet speeds when you reference connection. The simple answer would be as long as you’re using an Ethernet switch it will not slow down the connection in all likelihood. If the Ethernet switch you’re using has gigabit ports then your transfer speed on the switch will greatly surpass that of your internet download speeds. Even your cheapest gigabit switches will have transfer speeds in the gigabits per second range while most internet download speeds are 1/10 of that in the hundreds of megabits per second range.

I’m assuming you mean those splitters that use the “unused” pair in UTP wires. (So you need two splitters, one on either end, and I don’t think you’d have spare wires with power over ethernet.) And yes, they tend to mess up the signal, so the equipment on either side will probably sense the signal degradation and go to a lower speed. You’ll never get 1 gbps out of a splitter, and most likely no more than 10 mbps. It’s much better to use a switch at the end where you need multiple ports, instead. They’re cheap nowadays and give you full speed.

Well, it sort of depends on how you define “splitter”. If you mean switch, then as long as the interconnected Ethernet switches all share the same speed protocol set (like 1000BASE-T) you won’t get a slow down. If, on the other hand, you mean an RJ45 to RJ45 Ethernet cable coupler, then indeed this seemingly handy device can cause issues with speed and connection reliability. In fact, inserting one into an “Ethernet Channel” might cause a Fluke Certification test to fail as the performance of the channel will degrade outside of ANSI/TIA specifications for the given Category.

If by “splitters” you mean socket savers (adapters which split 1 cable into 2) then no, they simply use different wires within the cable. However, they only work up to 100 mbps. If on the other hand you mean switches (electronic circuits/device, such as you may find on the back of a broadband router) then they slow things down infinitesimally (by a factor of nano-seconds), unless the total bandwidth is saturated in which case things slow down a lot because, well, you are trying to share more than you have.
The cables that split in two rj45 connectors does not slow down a 100Mbps network. But they are only capable of transporting 100Mbps so they will slow down a 1000Mbps network.
